sec.p: This typology helps to show the close and frequently overlapping boundaries between the humanities and social sciences; often art is well positioned to highlight such commonalities (Bingham 2012). Specifically, this analysis encourages scholars, artists, and ethnographers working across disciplines to consider methodological questions around the nature of artistic versus social scientific storytelling. Questions about artistic storytelling techniques are a touchy subject for social scientists, as they invite “un-scientific” elements such as beauty, personal experience, emotions, or improvisation into the scientific endeavor. However, as my analysis shows, these techniques can be effective in catalyzing interest, curiosity, and moral/emotional commitment to a cause, which are also goals of the scientific endeavor. Further, artistic techniques might be useful for social scientists to tell their stories to a broader public (Chepp and Dean 2012).

This typology also serves as a guiding light for scholars and practitioners interested in social justice work by demonstrating the unique role of art in social change projects. Specifically, this framework provides a platform for rethinking existing models of how to foster civic engagement, particularly among marginalized communities. In the case of African American spoken word, art’s ability to evoke emotion and entertain serves to make public knowledge and everyday politics accessible and relevant to everyday citizens’ lives. As such, artistic forms that have an ability to be flexible (e.g., ephemeral, improvisational, or transportable) and evoke emotion among the masses (e.g., appeal to folk audiences), particularly through personal narratives, might be especially well positioned to incite social change by raising social consciousness through public knowledge projects, and making everyday forms of political action accessible through the use of artistic protest, dialogue, and pedagogy. At the time of this writing, the Occupy Movement is in full swing, and creativity has been identified as a core feature to the movement’s success (Kilkenny 2011). What if we were to expand this concept of creativity beyond the domain of creative social movement tactics and also considered the role of the creative arts in social change?

sec.title: Creative Politics and the Politics of Creativity
sec.p: In this concluding section, I consider questions around artistic creativity, social change, and impact. I introduce two related yet distinct theoretical concepts—creative politics and the politics of creativity—in an effort to show the relationship between the possibilities and limitations of everyday politics in artistic fields (Bourdieu 1984). On one hand, spoken word performance poets engage in creative politics by deploying artistic creativity as a political tactic, using their involvement in the performance poetry community as a vehicle for doing social justice projects aimed toward social critique and change. The typology introduced above provides a broader framework for understanding this alternative model of social activism. Poetry venues play an active role in the deployment and cultivation of creative politics in that they serve as incubators and outlets for artistic creativity. My conversations with venue representatives and my analysis of venues’ mission statements reveal that these poetry venues understand themselves to be a type of “free spaces” (Polletta 1999) in that they perceive themselves to be community institutions that support counterhegemonic ideas and identities through art, and where poets and audience members can dialogue and cultivate a political agenda.

However, in their efforts to carry out an agenda driven by creative politics, poet and poetry venues face many challenges. By the politics of creativity, I refer to the ways in which larger social structures are arranged so as to discourage creative artistic pursuits. In this way, artistic creativity—traditionally conceived of as an individualistic and perhaps exceptional human trait—has a politics associated with it in that it is a field of social struggle, where scarce resources, various forms of capital, and power are at stake. Many (but not all) of the poets in my study are “amateur” poets attempting to transition to living off their poetry, or at least supplementing their income through poetry. Securing adequately compensated—or compensated at all!—poetry-related work is an ongoing struggle for these poets; this includes adequate compensation for performing in shows, facilitating poetry workshops in schools or the community, and coaching youth poetry teams, among others. As such, their art serves as a form of un- or under-paid labor that is monetarily devalued, thus sharing characteristics with other forms of exploited, second shift labor (Hochschild [1989] 2003). Given spoken word performance poetry’s location within the structure of the larger art world (Becker 1982), poets lack access to various credentialing mechanisms (e.g., there is no academic degree or specialization available for spoken word poetry) and other professional art networks (such as publishing houses or a philanthropic audience) that could help support their artistic/political work. Although venues understand themselves to serve similar functions as other free spaces, many poetry venues face continuous financial challenges staying open, as well as staffing difficulties. The demand for good available poetry venues exceeds the supply, and poets consistently face difficulty trying to locate and maintain relationships with venues for their poetry events.

Yet, the poetry community is not helpless in face of these social structural constraints, and they use creative politics to respond and circumvent these constraints. Poets have managed to support their craft and, by extension their politics, by reconfiguring financial support networks and employing do-it-yourself (DIY) techniques—made accessible through democratic digital technologies—to cultivate a vibrant and politically charged artistic public sphere. For example, they self-publish their books and rely heavily on free social media to advertise. They create their own opportunities to institutionalize, legitimize, and monetize the art form and profession through roles such as the “teaching artist,” participating in slam competitions, and continuously establishing new DIY income-generating activities (e.g., a rotating monthly writing circle provides compensation for hosts). Such examples from my fieldwork demonstrate how an art-centered analysis offers a redefinition of political action and social activism, and at the same time illustrates the challenges to such alternative forms of political participation and social change.

fn.p: As an umbrella term, I follow Richard Bauman’s (2011) use of the phrase “spoken word,” referring to those sets of spoken word practices Bauman describes as “verbal art forms of oratory, theater, literature” (p. 6). He highlights verbal art forms such as chants, song, and oral poetry (e.g., folktales, legends, folksongs, and epics) in his discussion of spoken word “objects.” Here, Bauman (2011) uses the term broadly and interchanges it with “oral expression” and “oral tradition.” The term has also, however, become shorthand for contemporary performance poetry (Eleveld 2004, 2007; Olson 2007; Somers-Willett 2009). When referring to this more contemporary art form, I make it clear that I am specifically talking about spoken word performance poetry.

Traditionally, spoken word audiences have been a live community of listening spectators. The rising proliferation of YouTube and other digital technologies raises interesting new questions around audience and spoken word. For example, how have new recording technologies of voice and video afforded spoken word objects an ability to travel in a way that only written objects could circulate in the past? Do these new distribution patterns aid in or coopt the ability for spoken word art forms to carry subversive knowledges or political practices? Is something communicated in the live performance that cannot be relayed in the recorded performance?

Jackson ([1974] 2004) describes toasts as narrative poems from black American oral tradition, and he places them alongside other forms of oral folk poetry, namely work songs, spirituals, and the blues (p. vii).

The case for a tightly interconnected conception of culture, knowledge, and politics has already been made, albeit somewhat indirectly. Scholars have argued that knowledge should be studied and conceived of as culture (McCarthy 1996; Swidler and Arditi 1994) and that knowledge is synonymous with power (Foucault 1980; Lyotard [1979] 1984) and, by extension, politics. Others have shown how the cultural becomes political (Büyükokutan 2011), and specifically how art (i.e., a type of cultural object) is a means through which the political gets shaped (Negash 2004). Political scholars have demonstrated how cultural processes such as framing, emotions, and storytelling inform political action (Benford and Snow 2000; Goodwin and Jasper 2004; Polletta 2009), and political claims making (Tilly and Tarrow 2007). Scholars specializing in African American politics have illustrated how black Americans have historically turned to pop cultural mediums when excluded from more traditional institutionalized politics (Iton 2008), as well as how they articulate political thought through “everyday talk” in everyday cultural settings (Harris-Lacewell 2004).
For examples of work that refer to power as politics, see Collins’s (2004) discussion of black sexual politics and Foucault’s (2003) discussion of biopolitics.

Notably, Scott (1990) offers a way of looking at resistance within seemingly totalizing and all-encompassing power structures by examining peasant revolutions and slave revolts, among other more “hidden” forms of social critique and subversion. Such an analysis offers a platform from which to imagine an alternative to Horkheimer and Adorno’s (1944) critique of the culture industry, in which they argue that the engine of capitalism is too strong to produce artistic and cultural objects capable of challenging existing power structures and inciting social change.

Like Scott (1990), I understand transcript to mean a complete record of speech acts (i.e., what was said) and nonspeech acts (i.e., what was done, e.g., gestures and expressions). As such, I often refer to a transcript as a set of discourses and practices. Scott defines the public transcript as the body of social evidence that reveals how subordinates and dominant elites openly interacted.

Both elites and subordinates contribute to their hidden nature: elites are not privy to such discourses and practices, so they make no appearance in the public record, and subordinates are well adept at concealing them, so they make no appearance in the public record.

My understanding of knowledge includes my use of the term truth-telling, which evokes a sense of testimony and knowledge claims making from the perspective of one’s social location or standpoint. For further discussion on standpoint epistemology, see, for example, Smith 1990 and Collins 2000.
The concept of emancipatory knowledge is largely associated with the critical theorists of the Frankfurt School, and the description I offer here resembles Jürgen Habermas’s (1971) use of the term.

Black American spoken word culture can be traced to various African oral traditions (Asante 1998); some examples of African oral forms include storytelling by West African griots, the finn duri—literally, “fertility of long ago”—of the Gabra people in East Africa (and Oromo culture more generally; Kassam 1986), and the Basotho of Southern Africa (Lesotho; Coplan 1993). While oral traditions run deep throughout various cultures across the African continent and Diaspora, due to transatlantic slave trade patterns from Africa to the United States between the seventeenth and nineteenth centuries, the oral practices among West African cultures most likely informed the oral practices of slave communities in the United States.

Slam poetry is competitive performance poetry carried out in front of a live audience. During a slam, poets recite originally-authored, 3-min poems, after which audience members immediately judge the poems by assigning points to each artist’s performance. The highest-scoring poet wins the slam (Glazner 2000; Somers-Willett 2009).
I interviewed some respondents more than once, as follow-up interviews comprise an important component of ethnographic interviewing (Spradley 1979).

Of the community members I interviewed, 10 are women and 13 are men. Thirteen identify as black, seven as white, one as Arab and white, one as South Asian, and one as Filipino American. Seven identify as queer, gay, lesbian, or bi; one has a physical disability and two others work with students with special needs. Although I argue that contemporary spoken word poetry is rooted in a larger tradition of black American verbal art, the modern-day form is practiced by a racially diverse community of artists. Nonetheless, socially marginalized groups, including African Americans, continue to gravitate toward the art form as a means of expression, and one’s marginalized status—and the various injustices that ensue from these power arrangements—frequently serves as the topic of performance poetry (Somers-Willett 2009).

Max Weber uses ideal types as a conceptual tool to analyze empirical conditions. Here, “ideal” does not refer to a utopian type, but rather to an idea-construct that emphasizes the most common features of a given phenomenon in an effort to render the chaos of social reality into a systematic and examinable order. While Weber employs a comparative method in order to decipher patterns of historical change, I use the concept as a way to talk about a variety of verbal art forms in the abstract, while still recognizing the great diversity of styles and types within each genre.

These elements diverge from the four cultural elements Griswold (2008) identifies in her concept of the cultural diamond: cultural object, producers, receivers, and the social world. The cultural diamond is a device aimed to help understand how any cultural object relates to the social world. While I draw upon Griswold’s idea of the cultural object as a way to conceptualize verbal art performances, in the context of spoken word Griswold’s cultural diamond becomes fuzzy as producers and receivers coincide. That is, receivers (the audience) are also participating producers in creating the art form, and producers (the performing artists) are also receivers (shaping their art form in response to the reaction they receive from the audience). I also draw attention to cultural processes in my typology and, while processes are not absent from Griswold’s model, they are given a different emphasis in that they show relationships between elements (objects, producers, receivers, and the social world) rather than function as an element in of themselves.
I have assigned fictitious names to the spoken word poets in order to protect their anonymity.

Lord (1960) critiques multiple authorship theory in the context of all those who participated in singing Homer’s texts, suggesting that such a theory implies a concrete original text, which is not the case “in the flux of oral tradition” (p. 152). For my purposes, I use the term multiple authors to connote community-based or collaborative texts, and I make no claims about an original fixed text.

My understanding of social complexity refers to levels of social interaction associated with the cultural object, audience, and process, whereby each social phenomenon can be understood as being roughly located at the micro-, meso-, and macro level, respectively. This is an imperfect theoretical framework for understanding these phenomena, but is useful nonetheless in that it offers a way to conceptualize the relationships among these discrete phenomena.
